setup.question: How did Hendricks outfit the ship for war?
answers: She outfitted the ship for discovery, not war
She had additional screens installed to withstand combat

Text.text:
two things: a) im not even gonna lie this is prob one of the best stories ive read. b) A is not great answer, I think scientific discovery is what they're trying to refer to. 

Context:
aka Captain
and his exec crew receive a message for the warship
aka
aka
to

. 
Ivy Hendricks, romantic interest of cpt. Strike. She is in charge of Project warp, a project testing warp space—think hyperspace in star wars.
This is what happens upon arrival of the substation:
They have developed warp tech in labs and are using the ship as the first test for using it on a ship:

The original lab experiment used "a screen system." one of few references to screens. Hopefully this will also show that this is cutting-edge new tech and only for the purpose of testing/discovery than war.
"until
your quotes seem all over the place which disinclines me to believing you as it would be too easy for you to take them out of context. Please fill in the gaps btwn the quotes

can you at least read the quotes next time to tell me which quote you want me to expand on? I don't know which ones you find relevant or not. I'd be happy to give you the whole context but I can't do that on every single one. 

All caps part is a telegraph command.

Here is ev that the same ship being called different names:
ev. from dialogue between Hendricks and the crew:

The names part is where I'm confused at first. "The Cleopatra", "Lover-Girl", and "Old Aphrodisiac" are three distinct names and the paragraph doesn't seem to indicate that they're used interchangeably even though they appear in the same section
Okay if that's your concern no worries. Lots of ev to back it up:
Tethys is the planet with the experimental substation they are going to:

ran out of words but can cite the entire line if you want me to. 

this is it both referred to Lover-girl and Cleopatra. Cleopatra is the official name. Also the name on the telegraph. Lover-Girl and Old Aphrodisiac are names the crew calls the ship out of affection. The crew are a very tight knit and call themselves "family" 

If you look at the quotes section, you can also see the crew refer to the ship as Cleopatra and Lover-Girl when asking about what what Hendricks is doing to the ship. (Cob calls her Lover-girl and Celia calls her Cleopatra) If you are concerned that they are part of different crews I can also give ev of that.

Cool, that part seems to be cleared up. Can you expand on 1982-1988 preferably with quotes and explain what "this screen system" is referring to? Also please prove why this screen system would not be used in the context of combat.

No problem. This is basically Hendricks explaining to the crew how they developed hyperspace travel. The crew were worried what Hendricks was doing to the ship and when she explained that she was giving it hyperspace travel they were skeptical because it wasn't thought to be possible.

Clarifying that the screen system is meant to just be some hyperspace contraption. 
Asides from clarifying what a) the screen system is, b) that it is a new prototype that the navy is testing out, c) it is meant as a discovery mission, I'm not sure how else I can prove that the screen isn't used for combat. It's meant for hyperspace. Let me know your concerns. 
 
I can give you quotes of when they use hyperspace later during the war in order to escape.

Provide ev from before "that's been the view up to now," what has been the view? Also, what is the combat in the question referring to? There has to be some element of combat involved for the question to even be posed so I'd like an explanation of that
Here's ev for your first question:

I think it's because they go to war and also use the hyperspace thing to escape during combat 
This is them going to war:
more ev if you want

I'm looking through the quotes panel and I think you've let slip some quotes that lead me to believe B.

"See to it that my ship is fueled and armed for space within three hours!" where armed refers to combat, not just discovery. 

"Regulations say that fighting ships can not be held inactive during wartime" would provide a reason for Hendricks to be required to fight in the war.

Additionally, you've conceded that screens /are/ outfitted which is a win con for B.

answers.reason for outcome: Idk man this debate was so confusing and debater A was sus
i think i see where the judge mistook the ev. But i still Shree focused too much on what is sufficient to prove B even though A is a much better answer. I do see how it can be confusing.
